content.title: Lung Transplantation
content.summary: Lung transplantation is the definitive treatment for select patients with end-stage lung disease refractory to medical therapy. Common indications include COPD, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), cystic fibrosis, and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Careful candidate selection, lifelong immunosuppression, and vigilance for complications including chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) are essential.
key_points: Indications: end-stage COPD, IPF, cystic fibrosis, PAH unresponsive to medical therapy
Bilateral lung transplant preferred for suppurative diseases (CF, bronchiectasis)
Chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) is leading cause of late mortality
Contraindications: recent malignancy, active infection, non-compliance, significant comorbidities
content.statement: Lung transplantation offers survival and quality of life benefits for carefully selected patients with end-stage lung disease, but requires lifelong immunosuppression, vigilant monitoring, and management of complications including chronic lung allograft dysfunction.

explanation.intuition: Lung transplant is like getting new lungs when your own are failing and nothing else helps. It's a major decision because it trades one set of problems (end-stage lung disease) for another (immunosuppression complications, rejection). The transplanted lungs are exposed to the outside world with every breath, making rejection and infection constant concerns.
explanation.key_insight: The major long-term challenge is chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD), which affects ~50% of recipients by 5 years. CLAD presents as progressive airflow obstruction (BOS subtype) or restrictive changes (RAS subtype). There is no effective treatment once established, making early detection and prevention critical.
explanation.technical_details: Lung allocation is based on the Lung Allocation Score (LAS), which prioritizes patients based on expected survival benefit. Bridge to transplant with ECMO is increasingly used for decompensating patients. Ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) has expanded the donor pool by reconditioning marginal donor lungs.

definitions_glossary.lung_transplant: Surgical replacement of diseased lungs with donor lungs
definitions_glossary.single_lung_transplant: SLT; one lung replaced; may be option for IPF, COPD
definitions_glossary.bilateral_lung_transplant: BLT; both lungs replaced; required for suppurative diseases
definitions_glossary.LAS: Lung Allocation Score; prioritizes candidates based on medical urgency and expected survival benefit
definitions_glossary.primary_graft_dysfunction: PGD; ischemia-reperfusion injury causing early post-transplant respiratory failure
definitions_glossary.acute_cellular_rejection: ACR; T-cell mediated rejection; presents as dyspnea, infiltrates, declining FEV1
definitions_glossary.CLAD: Chronic lung allograft dysfunction; progressive irreversible decline in FEV1 >20%
definitions_glossary.BOS: Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome; obstructive CLAD phenotype
definitions_glossary.RAS: Restrictive allograft syndrome; restrictive CLAD phenotype; worse prognosis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Replacement of non-functioning lung tissue with healthy donor lungs

indications.COPD: Most common indication worldwide; usually single or bilateral
indications.IPF: Second most common; bilateral preferred due to rapid progression of native lung
indications.cystic_fibrosis: Third most common; BILATERAL required to prevent cross-contamination
indications.PAH: Less common now due to improved medical therapy; bilateral or heart-lung
indications.other: Bronchiectasis, sarcoidosis, LAM, occupational lung disease

transplant_types.single_lung: Shorter surgery, one donor serves two recipients; appropriate for restrictive diseases
transplant_types.bilateral_sequential: Both lungs replaced; required for CF, bronchiectasis
transplant_types.heart_lung: Rarely done; for Eisenmenger syndrome or end-stage PAH with RV failure

indications: End-stage lung disease despite maximal medical therapy
High mortality risk without transplant (LAS factors)
Potential for improved survival and quality of life
general_criteria: Absence of significant extrapulmonary organ dysfunction

absolute: Significant liver, kidney, or cardiac disease (unless combined transplant)

differential_diagnosis: Other surgical options (lung volume reduction for COPD)
Palliative care if not a transplant candidate

maintenance.corticosteroids: Prednisone, typically tapered to low dose

immunosuppression.monitoring: Drug levels, renal function, infection surveillance

surveillance.spirometry: Home monitoring; decline may indicate rejection or CLAD

complications_management.PGD: Supportive care; severe cases may require ECMO
complications_management.acute_rejection: Pulse steroids (methylprednisolone); antithymocyte globulin for refractory
complications_management.CLAD: Azithromycin for BOS phenotype; no proven treatment for RAS
complications_management.infections: CMV, Aspergillus, Pseudomonas are common; treat aggressively

definition.@value: Surgical replacement of diseased lungs with donor lungs for patients with end-stage lung disease refractory to medical therapy

scopeNote.@value: Covers indications, candidate selection, immunosuppression, and complications including CLAD

learning_objectives: Differentiate single vs bilateral transplant selection
Describe the components of triple immunosuppression
Recognize chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) and its phenotypes
Outline common post-transplant infections and their prophylaxis
clinical_pearls: CF and bronchiectasis REQUIRE bilateral transplant - single lung would get infected
CLAD (especially RAS) has no effective treatment - prevention is key
Median survival ~6 years; better than end-stage lung disease without transplant
CMV mismatch (D+/R-) is highest risk for CMV disease
Declining home spirometry is often first sign of rejection or CLAD
common_misconceptions: Lung transplant cures the underlying disease - it trades diseases
Age is absolute contraindication - many centers transplant patients >65
All rejection is treatable - CLAD is irreversible
